December 16, 1990: Fiction
THE PLAINS OF PASSAGE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $24.95.) The experiences
of a couple on a trek on horseback across Europe in the Ice Age.
FOUR PAST MIDNIGHT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Four novellas about
horror and terror in the late-night hours.
THE WITCHING HOUR, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $22.95.) The relationship of a
professional woman, the descendant of witches, and a rich man she brings back
to life after he drowns.
CARL'S CHRISTMAS, by Alexandra Day. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A
picture story about a dog who takes care of a baby while its parents perform
Christmastime chores.
DAZZLE, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $21.95.) The familial, professional and
romantic life of an eighth-generation California woman who becomes a celebrity
photographer.
THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton
Mifflin, $17.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride.
MEMORIES OF MIDNIGHT, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $21.95.) The destiny of
an American woman is haunted by a vengeful Greek tycoon.
JURASSIC PARK, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $19.95.) A biotechnician's use of
genetic engineering to clone dinosaurs for a theme park threatens to become a
global emergency.
LONGSHOT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $19.95.) An author of survival guides
attempts to write about the world of horse racing.
THE WILD CHRISTMAS REINDEER, written and illustrated by Jan Brett.
(Putnam, $14.95.) Little Teeka responds to Santa's request that she get his
reindeer ready for the Christmas Eve ride.
LADY BOSS, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) Lucky Santangelo
schemes and maneuvers to get control of a major movie studio.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE RUBY KNIGHT, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) The second
volume in "The Elenium," a fantasy series.
THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to
America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978.
December 16, 1990
Non-Fiction
A LIFE ON THE ROAD, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $19.95.) The memoirs of the
itinerant television newscaster.
THE CIVIL WAR, by Geoffrey C. Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns. (Knopf,
$50.) From Fort Sumter to Appomattox, in words and pictures.
BO KNOWS BO, by Bo Jackson and Dick Schaap. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The
autobiography of the athlete who plays baseball for the Kansas City Royals and
football for the Los Angeles Raiders.
MILLIE'S BOOK, as dictated to Barbara Bush. (Morrow, $17.95.) The memoirs of
the English springer spaniel who lives in the White House.
AN AMERICAN LIFE, by Ronald Reagan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) The
autobiography of the 40th President.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced and cherished in various cultures and
centuries.
THE CAT AND THE CURMUDGEON, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown,
$17.95.) The continuing contentions of two curmudgeons, one feline, the other a
writer.
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $8.95.) An illustrated gift edition of the popular inspirational
essay, with new commentary.
GET TO THE HEART, by Barbara Mandrell with George Vecsey. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The autobiography of the country-music singer.
FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, by H. G. Bissinger. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) A high
school football season in Odessa, Tex.
YOU JUST DON'T UNDERSTAND, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $18.95.) The
different languages men and women speak.
SUDDENLY, by George F. Will. (Free Press, $19.95.) Essays about America's
success in the cold war and the strains now developing in its society and
Government.
POWERSHIFT, by Alvin Toffler. (Bantam, $22.95.) How the changes currently
occurring throughout the world are altering our daily lives.
BY WAY OF DECEPTION, by Victor Ostrovsky and Claire Hoy. (St. Martin's,
$22.95.) An account of the operations of Mossad, the Israeli spy service.
